title.narrative: SP Nigeria - Strategic Partnership

description.narrative: An inclusive and peaceful Niger delta, based on equity and sustainable development, in which local communties manage their natural resources effectively for sustainable green growth, and where the space for negotiations between communities, government and companies on oil impact and oil management is institutionalized.

The strategic partnership program focuses on 1 topic in Nigeria: Extractives. For decades communities in the Niger Delta suffered the negative consequences of oil and gas exploitation (pollution, insecurity, and loss of livelihood opportunities) while scarcely benefiting from job opportunities or the reinvestment of oil and gas revenue. Combined with corruption, poor governance, and ineffective enforcement of environmental laws, this has led to oil theft, illegal refining, and the international illegal trading of oil. In this context, the launch of the clean-up process (in line with the 2011 UNEP report ) in June 2016 by the Minister of Environment offers new hope and provides opportunities to lobby for the participation of the communities in the zonal and local governance structures that will supervise the implementation of the emergency measures and the clean-up. Lobbying efforts concentrate on the Federal Minister of Environment who is delaying access to funds already approved for the clean-up, and on the Hydrocarbon Pollution Remediation Project (HYPREP) in charge of the clean-up. The program partners advocate for inclusive implementation and organize exchange visits and strategy meetings to mobilize women to engage in the governance structures. A challenge for the cleanup is the negative impact of bunkering and artisanal refining. Community members are willing to start a dialogue with artisanal refiners, they are afraid of doing so due to the risk of violent reprisals. The program lobbies with the relevant security agencies to ensure peace in Ogoniland and the wider Niger Delta. Further advocacy opportunities aimed at including social and human rights aspects in the Environmental Impact Assessments that are obligatory for oil and gas companies

title.narrative: Peace Corporate Indictors
Number of beneficiaries reached (PE)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly/indirectly through activities implemented or services established/enabled/improved by a Cordaid peace, security and justice project/programme

comment.narrative: Direct beneficiaries (Indirect beneficiaries = not applicable for our advocacy interventions)

People that were directly reached through meetings, workshops. The number excludes people reached through media campaigns as we couldn't immediately and easily put a figure on this. The 3,416 was collectively provided by the CSOs during the reflection workshop in January. For indirect beneficiaries we arrived at the 30,000 figure during the workshop based on an estimate of an average of 500 people as beneficiaries per each of the 60 communities reached (including the 3,416 directly sensitized). While many partners provided gender breakdown during the workshop, a few others couldn't and said they needed to revert to to confirm. Since this is an estimate, there is no exact values for for either male or female. Of the 3,416 direct beneficiaries collectively provided by the CSOs during the reflection workshop in January, we estimate that slightly more male than female were reached by the partners (except by Kebetkache that only worked with women).

title.narrative: Peace Thematic Indicators
DD4: Number of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

description.narrative: Counts each occasion that the program partners succeed in engaging with a new lobby target (decision-makers and power holders) on an important advocacy topic.

comment.narrative: Counts each occasion that the program partners succeed in involving a new lobby target on an important topic.
Counts each occasion that the program partners succeed in involving a new lobby target on an important topic.

The advocacy initiatives include targeting legislators, traditional leaders, public servants, diplomats, etc. while the topics covered include livelihoods, ESHRIA integration, EIA amendment, ending artisanal refining, etc.

The advocacy initiatives include the partners engaging a number of key decision-makers at both state and national levels, as well as taking up advocacy topics like amending the EIA, ending artisanal refining, and developing KPIs for Ogoni clean-up. Futher are included: advocacy visit to NOSDRA regarding NOSDRA’s regulatory thresholds (Intervention and Target Values) for contaminants and review of KPI by CEHRD; group of media outside the Niger Delta; L&A action on bird infestation of farms (regarding improving livelihoods) by FACE; Meeting with Niger Delta Development Commission to scale up coordination and intervention on specific activities that supports the infrastructure of the emergency measures.

title.narrative: DD5: Number of CSOs with increased L&A capacities

description.narrative: Increased lobby and advocacy capacity of CSOs. The capacity is evaluated yearly.

comment.narrative: 8 programme partners and 52 other supported CSOs all working in the Extractive trajectory
Eight SP partners and 93 CSOs directly reached by them
Increased lobby and advocacy capacity of CSOs will be evaluated yearly.
SP partners and local women and youth organisations.

title.narrative: DD6: Number of implementing partners in security and justice projects

description.narrative: Number of CSOs directly partnering in the programme interventions.

comment.narrative: All 8 partners in Extractives trajectory
Number of CSOs is at least the number of partner organisations per country.
SP partners.

title.narrative: DD2: Number of laws, policies and norms/attitudes blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development

description.narrative: Number of concrete changes in policies or laws brought about through lobby and advocacy by the program partners.

comment.narrative: Legislation on HYPREP’s independence to solidify HYPREP’s role and functioning currently in the House.
Number of concrete changes in policies or laws brought about through lobby and advocacy by the program partners.

title.narrative: DD1: Number of laws, policies and norms, implemented for sustainable and inclusive development

description.narrative: Number of concrete changes in policy implementation brought about through lobby and advocacy by the program partners.

comment.narrative: Number of concrete changes in policy implementation brought about through lobby and advocacy by the program partners.

The Minister of Environment provided a new timeline for the completion of the first phase of the clean-up, assuring the public that government remains committed to immediately completing the first phase and moving to the next phase. HYPREP provided updates on the state of the clean-up which has reached 60% completion in many of the sites. The Bayelsa State Governor directed the State Ministry of Environment to carry out an independent investigation to investigate the possible cause(s) of the dead fishes

title.narrative: DD3: Number of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, and/or influencing the debate

description.narrative: Number of times lobby and advocacy targets (decision-makers and power holders) include CSOs in the decision making process or react upon the issues brought forward by the program partners.

comment.narrative: Kebetkache nominated a group of women, who participated in the Forum on ‘Role of communities in the implementation of the clean-up process’. / Other occasions include HYPREP-CSO interactive session; high-level policy dialogue on Ogoni cleanup; rally/roadshow to speed up Ogoni clean-up; validation of the integrated baseline report; review of environmental regulatory thresholds for polluted sites remediation; advocacy visits/meetings to two Senators and a Minister; and advocacy meetings by PWYP for amending the EIA Act.
Number of times L&A targets include CSOs in the decision making process or react upon the issues brought forward by the program partners.
Number of times L&A targets include CSOs in the decision making process or react upon the issues brought forward by the program partners.

These include through press releases, during engagement with legislators including the Chairman of House Committee on Environment, and through the development and use of scorecard and advisory note. The Senate Committee then requested CEHRD to help prepare a draft bill on the legislation of HYPREP for deliberation in the Senate. The CBN (Central Bank of Nigeria) Development Finance Officer invited FACE Initiative and ADF to its periodic briefing of farmers and agribusiness operators to jointly develop appropriate strategies for agricultural development in Bayelsa State. Federal Ministry of Environment requested for PWYP input for the development of their position on EIA Amendment process. The Minister of Environment backed CSO Strategic notes to the Federal Executive Council to secure approval to restructure HYPREP. The Minister of State for Environment responded to Community Concerns in the Ogoni Clean-Up process. NOSDRA arranged a Joint Investigative Visit (JIV) with the Ministry of Environment, FACE Initiative, and Akassa Development Foundation.

title.narrative: Perception of civil society actors on civic space (space for engagement of civil society)

comment.narrative: Score 3 on a scale of 0-4. Majority (87%) of sampled civil society actors believe the civic space in Nigeria is only obstructed, not closed nor shrinking. More than half of the civil society actors (53%) believe CSOs are usually seen as partners by the Nigerian state actors with 71% agreeing that the Open Government Partnership (OPG) has helped to increase the civic space in Nigeria. Hence the satisfactory perception of the civil society actors on space for engagement.

title.narrative: Number of people (disaggregated by gender) reached with awareness raising

comment.narrative: Number of people reached with awareness raising at different events organized by SP partners
Number of people reached with awareness raising at different events organized by SP partners

title.narrative: Number of consultation processes with communities for policy dialogue with decision-makers

comment.narrative: PWYP engaged 90 representatives of different communities across six states during the state-level training on Integrating Environmental, Social and Human Rights into Impact Assessment & Biodiversity Audit
These are the number and groups of communities (e.g. women's groups) where consultations have been held

title.narrative: Number of processes for adoption and implementation of policies and legalisation

comment.narrative: Consultation was held with community members from Tai, Khana, Eleme and Gokana at a town hall meeting to engage policy makers on the status of the implementation of the UNEP report.
The processes include those initiated by the legislators in the national assembly; by Central Bank of Nigeria and NIRSAL for supporting farmers in Bayelsa

title.narrative: Number of networks with increased capacities to coordinate joint actions

comment.narrative: The partners have helped to form or strengthen these networks which include Ogoni Women Coalition, CSO Coalition, JADOC, YOULEAF
This is the number of other CSOs (including media groups) involved in the SP program with improved L&A capacity or increased involvement in L&A.

title.narrative: Number of communities involved in L&A initiatives

comment.narrative: Communities that were reached or represented in the different L&A activities carried out by the partners.
The communities include Agbi, Ekpangbala, Gio, Kporghor, Mogho, K-Dere, Kpean, Buan, Luerre Beeri, Bomu, Biara, Gbe, B-Dere and Kwawa in Rivers and
The number includes 146 communities reached directly and indirectly by Kebetkache; 4 reached by FACE; 10 communities by MacJim

title.narrative: Number of communities reached (SJ)
Number of campaigns to influence policy dialogue

comment.narrative: Campaigns towards integrating ESHRIA into the EIA policy led by PWYP; #SolidarityAcrosstheNiger media campaign
Roadshow/rally in Abuja led by Centre LSD and 16 Days of Activism Against GBV by FACE in Yenagoa (Bayelsa) and KEBETKACHE in Port Harcourt (Rivers)
The campaigns include speedy clean-up of Ogoni, EIA amendment, involvement of women in decision making, and sustainable rice cultivation

title.narrative: Number of reports with local evidence reflecting perspectives of target groups made available

comment.narrative: CEHRD just published an Integrated Environmental, Health, Human Rights and Gender Baseline for Ogoniland Clean-up. The report Is expected to be used as a tool to monitor the clean-up and also as an evidenced based advocacy tool to policymakers
Mac-Jim Foundation's (1) Survey on Impact of Sensitization Intervention and (2) FGDs for Livelihood Mapping in Elebele and Agbura Community in Ogbia and Yenagoa LGAs
These include research reports and knowledge products developed from gathered data from meetings, etc.

title.narrative: Peace Project Specific Indicators
D) CSOs organize in networks to build collaborate capacity for lobby and advocacy

comment.narrative: All SP CSO partners belong to one or more networks or coalition of CSOs such as the National Coalition on Gas Flaring and Oil Spill in the Niger Delta (NACGOND). Through their membership of NACGOND, SP partners have been able to use thier L&A skills to influence the activities and direction of the coalition, and by extension to address Ogoni clean-up issues. Other SP partners like CISLAC, Center LSD and CEHRD continue to facilitate forums of up to 50 CSOs thereby increasing the capacity and reach of more CSOs in lobby and advocacy. Some of the CSO networks have mobilized communities, made press releases, written petitions, and directly engaged with authorities. More CSOs are now involved in advocating to HYPREP to begin full implementation of the emergency measures and clean-up.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Participants from CSOs and media appraised the plans and activities of the Journalists Against the Delay of Ogoni Clean-up (JADOC) and the media during a webinar organized by Centre LSD to assess the role of the media in the clean-up. Following the event, the group produced more compelling feature articles on the clean-up. The group also formed the Bayelsa Chapter of JADOC to expand its membership and reach in the Niger Delta

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Members of the Civil Society Coalition on the Ogoni Cleanup (CISOC) out of dissatisfaction with the quality of contractors engaged by HYPREP resolved at their quarterly review meeting that the Monitoring sub-committee formed last quarter will visit three sites to validate the report and for the coalition to engage HYPREP in ensuring due process is adhered to.
A group of journalists engaged and sensitized by Center LSD on the role of the media in the Implementation of the UNEP Report on the Environmental Assessment of Ogoniland have formed the Journalists Against the Delay of the Clean-Up (JADOC) to deepen lobby and advocacy efforts towards ensuring speedy and effective implementation of the emergency measures and cleanup of oil spills in the Niger Delta. Similarly, media organizations outside the Niger Delta which were mobilized by CISLAC through a Media-CSO Training on KPI Monitoring, Lobbying and Advocacy Strategy have formed a #SolidarityAcrosstheNiger campaign. The campaign has already aired on Buharimeter, which was commissioned by Centre for Democracy and Development (CDD) to track the policies of the Buhari-led government.
Members of the Coalition of Ogoni Women Development Initiative, a coalition of community women groups in Ogoni which was formed earlier in the year with support from Kebetkache to advocate for the implementation of the UNEP report and the emergency measures, have now formulated their vision, mission and objectives. They also adopted a workplan and drafted a radio jingle as an advocacy tool.
A group of volunteers CSOs (Synergycare Development Initiative, BANGOF and OHEP) formed an alliance with Mac-Jim Foundation to initiate sensitization programs against bunkering and artisanal refining in several communities in Bayelsa State.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The Coalition of Ogoni Women Development Initiative met in January 2020 and developed an annual work plan that will guide the activities of the coalition, including its lobby and advocacy interventions for the clean-up of oil spills and implementation of emergency measures in Ogoni. Their focus is on women inclusion in the clean-up process; advocating for provision of clean water by HYPREP as part of emergency measures; and improving Ogoni women's livelihoods.
The Coalition of Ogoni Women Development Initiative and CSO Coalition for Ogoni Clean-up set up a Situation Room for periodic review of the clean-up process and implementation of the emergency measures. The two groups also set up a WhatsApp chat group and adopted a plan for field monitoring for the same purpose of jointly reviewing the clean-up process.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The quarterly HYPREP-CSO Interactive Session, formation of Ogoni Women Coalition for Community Development, the work of the Ogoni Clean-up Group (OCG) and formation of Journalists Again the Delay of Ogoni Clean-up (JADOC) remain important platforms for CSOs and similar interest groups working for the implementation of the emergency measures and clean-up in Ogoni to build synergy and increase the impact of their work. The HYPREP-CSO Interactive Session has helped to evolve a more cordial working relationship between the two parties while the women coalition is enabling individual women and women groups to come together to raise a common voice or take a joint position in making demands on issues that affect them.

title.narrative: E) Communities organize inclusive dialogue in which women, youth and minority groups can voice their needs and concerns

comment.narrative: Following sensitization by an SP CSO (MacJim), youths in Igbetaewoama in Nembe LGA initiated and had a peaceful engagement with HYPREP to discuss their participation in the clean-up exercise.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Community women, supported by other stakeholders, agreed to a resolution to protest to HYPREP in order to put more pressure on the agency to urgently provide clean water to Ogoni communities so that all communities can have the most essential substance (water) to prevent or fight COVID-19 pandemic.
Community members and CSOs from Gokana, Khana, Eleme and Tai LGAs validated the findings from the women livelihood assessment thereby making the research to be participatory.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): After benefitting from a Life Skills/ Entrepreneurial Training on Agriculture facilitated by Mac-Jim Foundation and funded by the Nembe Kingdom Youth Congress, the Nembe community organised an inclusive dialogue to identify and voice out the needs of youths in the community so that these could be addressed through farming and other legal, sustainable means. The dialogue led to the community’s youth security task force initiating its first meeting with the Joint Task Force (JTF) to expand and complement its already established regular meetings with the police. The meeting with the JTF led to some agreements on ways to better secure the communities from bunkering, pipeline vandalism and artisanal refining. A small group of youths that participated in the training and community dialogue also openly renounced their involvement in bunkering and artisanal refining. Furthermore, at a media briefing to mark 16 Days of Activism against Gender-Based Violence (GBV), groups of women organizations voiced out their concerns on gender-based violence and made demands such as the domestication of the Violence Against Person Prohibition (VAPP) Act in Rivers State. The Act was signed into law by the federal government in 2015. The media dialogue between the women and local journalists helped to amplify the concerns and interests of the women in different local and national news media.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): An interactive community - media roundtable was jointly organized by a civil society partner (Kebetkache) and women groups in three LGAs in Ogoniland during the period under review. Women representatives at the media roundtable voiced out their dissatisfaction over HYPREP's failure to consult or engage women from the communities on the agency's plan to train 1,200 women on skills acquisition.
Women from Alode-Eleme, Abua, Okwuzi, Erema, K-Dere, B-Dere, Umuechem and KroKro also resolved to form a network of Ogoni community women groups to advocate for speedy implementation of the emergency measures following their interactions with women from other oil impacted communities.
Fifteen women from Ogoni communities participated in a forum on the ‘Role of communities in the implementation of the clean-up process’ and used the event to raise their interests and concerns with regards to the implementation of the emergency measures and the cleanup process.
Eleme Council of Female Chiefs held dialogue with their chiefs on the high rate of killings and violence, resulting in the Council of Chiefs making strong pronouncement against the involvement of community members in rape, killings and kidnappings.

title.narrative: H) Government institutions, private sector and civil society develop structural dialogue and engagement

comment.narrative:
HYPREP and CSOs developed a partnership model for both parties to engage each other and for supporting the clean-up process and provision of the emergency measures.
The General Manager of Bayelsa Radio Station offered additional weekly slots to Mac-Jim Foundation to anchor a phone-in program for engaging the public to share their observations or concerns on the impact and trend of artisanal refining, oil bunkering and other related environmental issues.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): During the Agric Value Chain (AVC) workshop, NIRSAL developed a communique with CSOs, farmers and agribusiness operators recommending policy/strategy to be adopted by government to improve agriculture in Bayelsa State, based on the peculiarity of the state. Sensitization activities by Mac-Jim Foundation in collaboration with the Bayelsa Non-Governmental Organizations Forum, contributed to the annual CSOs, Government and Shell Petroleum Development company Dialogue and Engagement in Yenagoa, Bayelsa State. The stakeholders meeting facilitated by PWYP in Abuja in May 2019 resulted in the setting up of a Working Group comprising government MDAs and CSOs for dialogue and engagement for policy reforms on ESHRIA.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The Special Adviser to the President on SDGs initiated a tripartite meeting with his office, HYPREP and Office of the Secretary to the Government of the Federation (SGF) to discuss ways to complement the delivery of HYPREP’s mandate. An actionable framework is expected to be worked out by the tripartite committee. Similalry, HYPREP and Ministry of Water Resources & Rural Development held an inaugural meeting to discuss provision of water to impacted communities. They both set up a joint technical working committee to facilitate the partnership.
The Nigeria National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) and Department for Petroleum Resources (DPR) resolved their inter-agency rivalry by reconciling their differences at a multi-stakeholders meeting for Integrating Environmental, Social and Human Rights into Impact Assessment & Biodiversity Audit. The two organizations had not been together at any meeting in a long time until the stakeholders meeting organized by PWYP. This is expected to pave the way for future integration of ESHRIA in the respective organizations’ mandates in the national environmental management governance framework.

title.narrative: J) Stakeholders support the role of civil society and assure that the voice of communities and minority groups are heard in policy dialogue

comment.narrative:
HYPREP publicly appreciated the role of CSOs in ensuring effective clean-up and assured it will dialogue and work with CSOs to address the challenges in the clean-up process.
HYPREP approved a dedicated CSO Desk for the project to interface with CSOs and share information with them regularly. The organization also committed to develop and present its communication strategy for engaging more effectively with CSOs and communities in Q1 2019.
The Permanent Secretary, Ministry of Environment, Bayelsa State agreed with the need for establishing Environmental Desks at Local Government Councils and requested the support of Mac-Jim Foundation to organize a roundtable with stakeholders towards achieving this objective.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The Senate and House Committees on Environment appreciated the study and findings on the integrated baseline assessment and accepted the report as a working document for the committees as it pertains to their oversight functions on environmental issues.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Oil Producers Trade Section (OPTS) Executive Director conveyed the resolution of the body to continue to partner with CSOs and other stakeholders, and not take different approaches that may slow down the implementation of the clean-up. The Director, Ministry of Environment regarded FACE Initiative as an active CSO working on environmental issues in Bayelsa State and thus shortlisted FACE to participate in an upcoming stakeholders meeting on environment being planned by Bayelsa State government.
The Bayelsa State Ministry of Environment nominated and deployed four of its officials to participate along with FACE Initiative in conducting the sustainable alternative livelihoods assessment for generating evidence for ending bunkering and artisanal refining and improving livelihoods in oil impacted communities.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Several stakeholders including the Federal Ministry of Environment and HYPREP publicly recognize the role of the partnership in addressing pending Ogoni clean up issues. Specifically, a Federal Ministry of Environment team acknowledged PWYP as a working partner with regards to integrating ESHRIA and biodiversity audits, and re-introducing a fresh Bill on Amending the EIA to the 9th Assembly. The Ministry team canvassed for PWYP to make presentation on ESHRIA and Biodiversity Audits to senior decision makers in the Ministry. The Manager of the Agriculture Development Program (ADP) of Bayelsa State Ministry of Agriculture committed himself and his office to partner with FACE to train farmers and community members on modern farming techniques and also connect them with extension workers across the state for mentoring and on-the-spot support for farmers. He took this position in recognition of the role of FACE and other CSOs in achieving the mandate of ADP

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The Managing Director of ZAL (a CBN agent that trains old and prospective SMEs on basic SME skills such as development of proposals and business plans for CBN funding) agreed to conduct a Train the Trainer (ToT) programme for representatives of FACE Initiative. The ToT will enable FACE to in turn train communities on developing winning proposals or business plans for CBN SME support. This collaboration will broaden the reach of CBN SME programme and create greater opportunities for people in the grassroots.
HYPREP invited the Executive Director of Kebetkache to join the members of the House Committee on Environment to visit HYPREP project sites in Gokana and Eleme LGAs - a further recognition by HYPREP of the important role of CSOs in the clean-up.

title.narrative: (SP) Number of agreements supported by official documents for the adjustment and design of policies and for and policy implementation

comment.narrative: Include a formal letter by the Senate to HYPREP for public presentation and discussion of proposed Ogoni clean-up KPIs; a request from CBN for a list of farmers to support in Bayelsa State; and NIRSAL's brief on recommended areas of support for agricultural support specific to Bayelsa State

title.narrative: N) National government institutions, international development actors and multinational companies implement laws and policies favourable to the target communities with transparent practices & systems

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The Minister of State for Environment responded during the media briefing on Community Concerns in the Ogoni Clean-Up process to Kebetkache’s tweet on the issue explaining that work will be concluded in some of the lots within the next two months. The PA to the Minister also called the Kebetkache ED to acknowledge the fact the Minister has seen the media statements. Dr Marvin, the PC of HYPREP is now following Kebetkache on Twitter as a result of the media briefing.
In a swift response to a portion of a press statement bordering on the need for a feasible timeline for the Ogoni clean-up, which was released by Centre LSD to commemorate the 2020 World Environment Day on June 4, the Minister of Environment provided a new timeline for the completion of the first phase of the clean-up, assuring the public that government remains committed to immediately completing the first phase and moving to the next phase.
Similarly, HYPREP followed suit and provided updates on the state of the clean-up by saying that work has further progressed and has reached 60% completion in many of the sites. This is a huge departure from the non-responsiveness of government agencies.
NODSRA arranged a Joint Investigative Visit (JIV) with the Ministry of Environment, FACE Initiative, and Akassa Development Foundation, to investigate the possible cause(s) of the dead fishes. This also led to the Bayelsa State Governor directing the State Ministry of Environment to carry out an independent investigation.

title.narrative: I) CSOs are influential in international multi-stakeholder alliances and platforms

comment.narrative: OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): A group of diplomatic officials in Nigeria including from the European Union, United States Embassy, Embassy of Belgium, Norwegian Embassy, Dutch Embassy, French Embassy and Canadian Embassy representing an international community or group were engaged for the presentation of the integrated baseline report. The diplomats indicated their readiness to continue to prioritize the clean-up of Ogoni, assist HYPREP as much as possible, and channel their interventions in line with the recommendations of the study.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Engagement with government MDAs, CSOs, media and other stakeholders created opportunity for Henrich Boll Foundation to support PWYP and other Cordaid partnership Partners to participate in a public hearing conducted by the National Assembly, and for the House of Representatives Committee on Environment and Habitats to propose / work on amending the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) Act. Henrich Boll Foundation also invited PWYP to make a presentation at an organised event to support the 2004 EIA Act amendment process.

title.narrative: (SP) Progress steps made by CSOs to organise data collection

comment.narrative: Currently at level 4 because data are being collected for the sustainable livelihoods assessment; expected to move to level 5 (data analysed and conclusion drawn) or level 6 (data shared, publicized or used for L&A ) by next quarter

Refers to progress with partners using the following scale (0-6) for the steps: 0. not yet started / 1. goal and purpose of data collection agreed upon / 2. methodology agreed upon and tasks divided / 3. data collectors trained and preparations ready / 4. data being collected / 5. data analysed and conclusion drawn / 6. data shared, publicized or used for L&A
While CEHRD has shared and validated the preliminary integrated baseline report, FACE and KEBETKACHE have only completed data collection = average of 6 + 4 + 4 = 4.7 or ~5. (On a scale from 0 to 6)

title.narrative: B) CSOs and Cordaid collect local evidence from target groups (with participatory data collection methodologies) for effective lobby and advocacy strategies and knowledge building

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): CSOs, community leaders and local monitors participated in a validation workshop to evaluate the success and impact of the implementation of the UNEP report during the period under review. CISLAC circulated a scorecard widely among communities, CSOs, media and legislators leading to the scorecard becoming a talking point among traditional and community heads while media organizations have requested for discussions and debates on the content of the scorecard. The National Assembly, House Committee on Environment resolved to use the report to declare an emergency on the cleanup while River State House of Assembly has proposed a special session to discuss the findings.
PWYP conducted two perception surveys on ESHRIA and used the findings for the validation of ESHRIA policy brief, which in turn helped to enhance the direction of advocacy to policy makers.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): FACE Initiative conducted a survey and focus group discussions to collect information from community members in Bayelsa and Rivers states on the perception of the community members on the impact of oil spills on their livelihoods. Over 1,000 community men and women across 14 communities in both states participated in the livelihood assessment, which also reveals information on the strategies being adopted by communities to mitigate the impact of oil spills on livelihoods in the Niger Delta. Similarly, Kebetkache conducted Ogoni women’s livelihood needs assessment through which over 1,000 Ogoni women voiced out their livelihood challenges and needs.
Key stakeholders in the clean-up of oil spills in the Niger Delta including community leaders, CSOs, government decision makers and media were able to validate findings from the integrated baseline assessment conducted by CEHRD in 2019 during a research report validation meeting held during the period under review. The stakeholders were able to relate the findings of the research or determine their implications to their works or lives.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The SP partners, in particular FACE and Kebetkache, jointly reviewed the initial findings from two researches (sustainable livelihoods assessment by FACE and Capacity needs assessment of Ogoni women by Kebetkache) during the quarterly Progress Meetings in January 2020 to identify lobby and advocacy topics to engage stakeholders with.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Two important studies were conducted during the period under review, namely (1) impact of community sensitization against illegal bunkering and artisanal oil refining and (2) livelihood and poverty assessment - in selected communities in Bayelsa State.
FACE Initiative carries out surveys on the link between oil spill (through vandalism, bunkering and artisanal refining) and livelihood options and trends in selected communities in the Niger Delta. The aim is to generate insights in ways to end bunkering and artisanal refining. Preliminary findings mobilising concerned community members is an important factor. Further analyses are expected to show communities’ preferences or suggestions for sustainable livelihoods in the region, which in turn are expected to inform socio-economic planning by policy/decision makers.
MacJim Foundation in collaboration with Synergycare Development Initiative carried out a Focus Group Discussion (FGD) for livelihood mapping in Elebele and Agbura communities in Ogbia and Yenagoa LGAs respectively. Former artisanal refiners, dealers (marketers) of petroleum products from artisanal refining, farmers, and community leaders provided inputs into ways for ensuring sustainable livelihoods in the state.

SP Nigeria conducted five surveys, including baseline survey on UNEP emergency measures and inclusion of women in the cleanup process; baseline survey on Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA); and community perception survey. The surveys involved several communities and the findings therefrom used to engage both the communities and authorities. For instance, the SP used the findings from the community perception survey which revealed a wide communication gap between HYPREP and Niger Delta communities to advocate to HYPREP to improve its communication and engagement with the communities.

title.narrative: K) National decision makers initiate policy processes with inclusive civil society engagement

comment.narrative: OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The Senate Committee on Environment then requested CEHRD to help prepare a draft bill on the legislation of HYPREP for deliberation in the Senate.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The Federal Ministry of Environment made suggestions / inputs to the drafting of the ESHRIA policy brief – such as leaving the title as the EIA Act and not changing it to the ESHRIA Act as being proposed). This helps to enrich the content for the call for amendment and affirms the commitment of the Ministry towards the amendment of the Act. Federal Ministry of Environment requested for PWYP input for the development of their position on EIA Amendment process.
The Minister of Environment received and used the advisory note from CSO Strategic Meeting by presenting it to the Federal Executive Council to secure approval to restructure HYPREP.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): As a result of advocacy visits to HYPREP on the implementation of the emergency measures and clean-up, including the development of Key Performance Indicators (KPI) for the clean-up, HYPREP has now formally requested the service of CEHRD along with other CSOs to jointly review the current draft KPIs.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): PWYP was invited and participated in the public hearing by the House of Representatives Committee on Environment and Habitats to amend the 2004 EIA Act. PWYP supported in setting the agenda for the proposed amendment to include ESHRIA.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The Senate and House Committees on Environment appreciated the study and findings on the integrated baseline assessment and accepted the report as a working document for the committees, especially as it pertains to their oversight functions on environmental issues. The Senate Committee then requested CEHRD to help prepare a draft bill on the legislation of HYPREP for deliberation in the Senate.
The CBN (Central Bank of Nigeria) Development Finance Officer invited FACE Initiative and ADF to its periodic briefing of farmers and agribusiness operators to jointly develop appropriate strategies for agricultural development in Bayelsa State.

The Community Development Agency (CSDA) engaged an SP partner (Mac-Jim Foundation) to conduct a vulnerability assessment and sensitization in Ekeremor and Nembe Local Government Areas in order to support the agency’s work and service delivery to communities.

title.narrative: C) CSOs and Cordaid increase community awareness on advocacy topics

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Community women in K-Dere planted 50 trees in commemoration of 2020 World Environment Day and as parts of their initial contributions to the remediation of the Ogoni environment.
Several communities have taken a wide range of decisions and actions following their participation in a stakeholders meeting to share experience on efforts at curbing artisanal refining and improving alternative livelihoods in Bayelsa State. These actions include: - Ogbia community leadership in Nembe establishing an environmental surveillance group to monitor and report oil pipeline vandalism, illegal bunkering and artisanal refining. - Imiringi community leadership (in Ogbia) and Gbarain Clan (in Yenagoa) authorizing the youth bodies in the two communities to function also as an environmental surveillance group. - Okordia clan in Ikarama and Kalaba communities in Yenagoa established an environmental surveillance group with laws promulgated by the communities to protect livelihood activities against pipeline vandalism. This was done in partnership with the Joint Task Force (JTF) as persons caught in pipeline vandalism are handed over to the JTF security agency.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Community leaders in the oil impacted communities of K-Dere, B-Dere and Bonu now meet regularly to discuss and speak out about issues relating to the clean-up following a training on lobbying and advocacy strategies organized by CEHRD. Similarly, youths from the communities who were trained by CEHRD as Impact Monitors are now aware of possible impacts to look out for during the clean-up, and have started reporting clean-up activities in their communities to civil society organizations.
The community leaders expressed the need for working with government to achieve the ESHRIA objectives and the importance of including women and youths in decision making, following training by PWYP on Integrating Environmental, Social and Human Rights into Impact Assessment. 90 community leaders, representatives of 25 CSOs, representatives of 15 MDAs (including Ministry of Environment, National Human Rights Commission and Nigeria Police Force) participated in the training.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The programme continued to increase the awareness of communities in the Niger Delta on a range of topics and issues, including on the impact of oil pipeline vandalism, bunkering and artisanal refining; alternative livelihoods; women and youth empowerment; implementation and monitoring of emergency measures and clean-up process; conflict management; and integration of ESHRIA and biodiversity audits. Many coastal communities including Buoama, Kongho, Minibie and Bekekiri are now aware of the possibilities in practising sustainable agriculture in their areas following the sensitization and training interventions by the partnership with 12 beneficiaries of the training already cultivating coastal farmlands in Akassa, Brass LGA. Similarly, more communities like in Okordia Zarama are now effectively monitoring and reporting oil spills and conflict triggers to the authorities following their training on oil spillage monitoring and conflict management. New targets like the Forum of Ogoni Councillors and management of educational institutions like ACWA School in Ogbokiri have also been reached by the partnership and engaged on a wide range of topics leading to the former contributing to 2020 agenda setting for HYPREP and the latter establishing an Agric Club and a school farm.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The public presentation of the Integrated Baseline Report, and the follow-up meetings with various key stakeholders, raised the awareness of communities on current and emerging advocacy topics such as the next phase of HYPREP’s operations in Ogoniland and how communities can influence the outcomes. In addition, a press briefing on the key findings of the integrated baseline enabled the media to widely report and publicise the findings among various communities.
Community leaders in Apparanbie, Brass LGA of Bayelsa State have expressed readiness to upscale cassava cultivation and venture into other areas of agriculture, and to participate in joint advocacy to relevant government agencies to access improved crop seedlings and to establish cassava processing mill for enhancing yields and processing by the farmers.

The SP partners sensitized thousands of people across about 60 communities in the Niger Delta on a wide range of topics such as the implementation of the emergency measures and clean up, ending artisanal refining, and adopting alternative livelihoods. The partners carried out the sensitization activities through town hall meetings, focus group discussions, training workshops, road shows and media engagement. The sensitization helped the communities to increase their level of awareness on specific topics and issues, and to have balanced expectation of the Ogoni clean-up. It also helped some communities, especially the youths therein, to increase their agitation for inclusion in the clean-up exercise.

title.narrative: A) Civil society partners (CSOs) and Cordaid increase their capacity to influence and engage in dialogue with policy makers, politicians and companies

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Partners build their capacity to adopt and use information and communication technologies (ICTs like Zoom) to continue their lobby and advocacy activities. During the lockdown, the SP organized internal bi-weekly team meetings and a quarterly reflection meeting as well as virtual webinars and workshops for external stakeholders.
CISLAC organized quarterly CSO Strategic Meeting. The review of the performance of HYPREP till date was the focus of discussion and debate, resulting in end of the meeting that HYPREP had performed below expectation. Beyond the regular communique or press release, an advisory note suggesting steps to improve the agency’s performance and targeted at federal decision makers was developed.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): A group of 30 media editors representing major media houses in the Niger Delta have reached an understanding to henceforth properly regulate themselves and prioritize cleanup issues and stories following their participation in Media Engagement with Senior Environment Editors event organized by CISLAC to appraise reportage dichotomy between independence of media organization and government influence.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): The strategic partnership programme in Nigeria organized a workshop titled Extractives, Conflict and Fragility in August 2019 through which the programme team of Cordaid and CSOs gained more insights into the link between extractives on the one hand, and conflict and fragility on the other hand. The team explored and identified the major drivers and dynamics of conflicts, and gained better understanding of the current situation of conflicts and fragility in the extractive sector in Nigeria, especially with regards to the clean-up of oil spills in the Niger Delta. The team was able to reappraise the main actors in the extractive sector in Nigeria as well as the key lobby and advocacy strategies needed to mitigate or address conflicts and fragility in the sector.
Also during the period under review, the state-level stepdown training on the integration of environmental, social, health and human rights into impact assessment (ESHRIA) and biodiversity audits facilitated by PWYP enabled a number of CSOs within and outside the partnership to increase their capacity to advocate to different targets on the topic / issue of ESHRIA.

The civil society partners in the Strategic Partnership leveraged a L&A training workshop held in July 2018 and other learning opportunities like the quarterly reflection workshops to intensify their engagement with key stakeholders involved in the implementation of the Ogoni clean-up.With their new skills and confidence, the partners were able to more effectively engage key stakeholders such as the Office of the Vice President, HYPREP, national assembly and senate, and government ministries, departments and agencies. Stakeholders like HYPREP in turn publicly acknowledged the roles of the CSOs while others like the Ministry of Environment and NOSDRA engaged them to review policies and laws.

title.narrative: F) Communities increase their capacity for advocacy towards decision makers

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): the Coordinator of the Forum of Ogoni Councillors (selected district representatives) convened an extra-ordinary meeting to develop a position paper on the clean-up. The position paper detailed the demands of the Forum and was submitted to HYPREP for action.
The Forum of Ogoni Councillors set up a monitoring unit to collect feedback from communities and relay incidents to HYPREP. The monitoring unit is already investigating an incident / attack during the monitoring of the clean-up by the House Committee on Environment.
The Kpean community celebrated the selection of one of the contaminated sites in the community for remediation by HYPREP after several complaints by the community to the agency. This has boosted the resolve of the community to advocate for more sites to be selected for remediation, which HYPREP has promised will be done in the next phase of the assessment.
Community leaders in Apparanbie, Brass LGA of Bayelsa State have expressed readiness to upscale cassava cultivation and venture into other areas of agriculture, and to participate in joint advocacy to relevant government agencies to access improved crop seedlings and to establish cassava processing mill for enhancing yields and processing by the farmers.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Community groups and the ADF conducted advocacy to NOSDRA, Bayelsa State Government, Bayelsa State House of Assembly, Minisitry of Environment in response to the incidence of dead fishes being washed ashore coastal communities in Bayelsa and other Niger Delta States. They pressed on government at national and state levels to conduct joint investigation to ascertain the possible cause of death and compensate impacted communities for the loss of livelihood and other environmental impact resulting from the incident Community groups continued to enage CBN to secure their support in implementing alternative livelihood programmes in their communities,
Local community ESHRIA Monitors in Ogoniland who monitor the process and progress of work on clean-up sites and report environmental issues within their environment strengthened their capacities during their quarterly meeting. The youths are fully aware of HYPREP’s mandate as it relates to the clean-up of Ogoniland and capable of discussing environmental issues in their communities.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Communities in Okordia Zarama were able to point out to evaluators different irregularities and failures in the implementation of General Memorandum of Understanding (GMOU) between the communities and the Shell Petroleum Development Company (SPDC). The communities were able to do this during the process evaluation of the GMOU having been sensitized on the importance of participatory decision making and specifically guided in the use of the GMOU tool. Similarly, host communities of Dangote Cement Company in Obajana District of Kogi State leveraged the sensitisation and training on ESHRIA by partnership Nigeria / PWYP to begin advocacy for a new and more encompassing MOU with the company. It is also in the same vein that through partnership Nigeria’s training on understanding the UNEP report and managing conflict and fragility that the Forum of Ogoni Councillors was able to engage HYPREP, initiate a quarterly meeting and even set agenda for the agency for 2020.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): During the Town Hall Meeting on Coordination and Monitoring of the Clean-up, the Chairman of the Committee on Environment of the National House of Assembly (NASS) prompted to convene a public hearing for fact finding on the progress of the clean-up, especially at it relates to the work of HYPREP and other key stakeholders.
Following a capacity building workshop on Conflict Sensitivity, Peacebuilding and Mediation on the Clean-up for members of the Forum of Ogoni Councillors (selected district representatives), the Coordinator of the Forum convened an extra-ordinary meeting of the councillors to develop a position paper on the clean-up. The position paper detailed the demands of the Forum and was submitted to HYPREP for action. The Forum also set up a monitoring unit to collect feedback from communities and relay such to HYPREP. The monitoring unit is already investigating an incident / attack during the monitoring of the clean-up by the House Committee on Environment.
The Kpean community celebrated the selection of one of the contaminated sites in the community for remediation by HYPREP after several complaints by the community to the agency. This has boosted the resolve of the community to advocate for more sites to be selected for remediation, which HYPREP has promised will be done in the next phase of the assessment.
Rice farmers in Akassa have formed four cooperatives which will be registered with relevant government agencies and positioned to access agricultural support and services for farmers in Akassa. The community has also submitted an application for the provision of a modern cassava processing mill in the community.
The women in Alode-Eleme and Nsisioke communities sent a congratulatory message to the new King of Nchia-Eleme, Chief Ebebe, ahead of plans to visit and engage the new king on the issue of lack of drinking water in the communities, and the need for the traditional leader to prioritize access to clean water in his engagement with Eleme LGA and HYPREP.

OUTCOME(S): (Extractives): Women leaders from K-Dere, Alode- Eleme, Krokro, B-Dere and Erema communities also demanded the inclusion of women in the Central Representative Advisory Council (CRAC) following a learning exchange visit among women in oil impacted communities.
Communities from the three Local Government Areas of Eleme, Tai and Khana utilized a town hall meeting facilitated by CISLAC to dialogue on the status of the implementation of the UNEP report and interact with officials of HYPREP. The town hall meeting helped in clearing misconceptions about the cleanup project and in assuring the communities of HYPREP’s recognition and consideration of their needs.
Also in Rivers State, following his participation and orientation at a Training of Stakeholders on Monitoring and Evaluation of the Cleanup facilitated by CISLAC, King Leslie N. Eke of Evo Kingdom, Rivers State became committed that he volunteered to personally advocate to and influence the Governor of Rivers State to be more proactively involved in the cleanup process. He also showed his readiness to influence other traditional rulers to participate actively in monitoring the contractors handling the cleanup.
A prominent community member of Kongho community in Akassa took the initiative to prepare about an acre of land for rice farming in the area, engaging several youths in the process. As this contributes to job creation and is expected to contribute to increased food security and economic empowerment, the community leaders and youths are leveraging on this development to advocate to government and its agencies to provide relevant incentives and enabling environment for rice cultivation in the areas.

There was no organized women’s group in Kwawa when an SP partner (Kebetkache) first visited the community in October 2018. However, following capacity building for the women in the community, six of the women consulted with the council of chiefs to create a women’s group and another group for the female youths. The formation of the women's groups makes the Kwama women to be better organized and is bound to increase their capacity to demand for clean and safe drinking water which has been lacking in the community.
Training on EIA/ESHRIA for selected communities from Nembe, Ogbia, Yenagoa and Sagbama LGAs led to the community leaders appreciating the EIA/ESHRIA as a critical environmental management tool needed for assessing and avoiding major effects of oil projects in communities. Hitherto, the community leaders had regarded the EIA/ESHRIA as unnecessary and a waste of time, and had even turned down the conduct of EIA/ESHRIA in the past.

title.narrative: (SP) Number of communities involved in data collection and analysis of data for advocacy

comment.narrative: Elebele and Agbura communitiesy in Ogbia and Yenagoa LGAs respectively were involved in FGDs for Livelihood Mapping by MacJim; 12 communities were involved in the sustainable livelihoods assessment by FACE in Bayelsa

These are the communities involved in FACE's sustainable alternative livelihoods assessment, in KEBETKACHE's Ogoni women's livelihood needs assessment, and CEHRD's validation of the integrated baseline report
